author: sky.cactus
content: I have been thinking about escalator + 1559. It *feels* like 1559 already has a mechanism in place for "escalating" the base fee (in the form of the `feemax`).  So I feel like the escalator only really needs to push the `gas_premium` up with time.

author: sky.cactus
content: The `feecap` can be set to the max from the start since basefee is a "trustless" algorithm (economically) and not subject to miner exploitation like `gas_premium` is (miners don't directly control it).

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> So I feel like the escalator only really needs to push the `gas_premium` up with time.
<@!301186049323958275> 

this is also why i find the "floating escalator" to be the most reasonable among the three hybrids in the document (https://github.com/ethereum/rig/blob/master/eip1559/combination.md)

author: barnabemonnot
content: until your premium is bounded by your maxfee, the premium is what sets you "ahead of the pack" compared to other users who have transactions in the pool

author: barnabemonnot
content: so escalating the premium with the floating escalator retains the intuition of "climbing above" the rest

author: barnabemonnot
content: but then again, this is just a design, I didn't really think through yet whether this introduces bad incentives

author: barnabemonnot
content: nor whether this is desirable/useful

author: barnabemonnot
content: it does introduce a bunch more parameters even though a few can be set to reasonable defaults, so even from a UX perspective it's not a clear win

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming the function is shared by everyone, then it should just be 2 additional inputs?

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, actually maybe 3 inputs... (start, end, max_premium).

content: I can't make that, but I'm not much of a voice/video chat person anyway so I don't recommend trying to time it where I can make it.

author: sky.cactus
content: My current feedback on 1559 is in the form of a PR that is waiting to be merged or argued against.  üôÇ

author: timbeiko
content: Got it, I'll make sure to add your PR as a discussion point for the agenda to get everyone's thoughts.

author: kiwi.eth
content: Good by me!

author: kiwi.eth
content: <@!301186049323958275> mind linking your PR?

author: sky.cactus
content: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2635

author: kiwi.eth
content: üôè thank you

author: sky.cactus
content: I also have a concern that the during the migration period, large transactions will no longer be possible for a time.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, if a contract requires 8M gas to deploy, there will be a period of time during the migration where it is *impossible* to deploy that contract.

author: sky.cactus
content: Probably something worth discussing, though I don't have an actual solution for that.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> Hmm, actually maybe 3 inputs... (start, end, max_premium).
<@!301186049323958275> when working it out I found at least 4 parameters were necessary to fully define the space. if you can't specify the starting premium then you also cannot reproduce 1559-style transactions, nor start from a little over the basefee. but then yes either the maxpremium or the maxfee or both makes sense

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> For example, if a contract requires 8M gas to deploy, there will be a period of time during the migration where it is *impossible* to deploy that contract.
<@!301186049323958275> is that because the gas pool in a block is split between 1559 txs and regular transactions?
